clinical_study.brief_title: Laryngeal Disorders After Childhood Cardiac Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Prevalence of Laryngeal Disorders After Childhood Cardiac Surgery and Evaluation of Their Long-term Recovery

brief_summary.textblock: Laryngeal disorders after childhood cardiac surgery is a complication well described in the literature. However, the long term progression of the affected children has never been studied (all the studies stopped before 2 years of follow up).

primary_outcome.measure: Prevalence of a laryngeal mobility disorder after childhood cardiac surgery
primary_outcome.description: The prevalence will be evaluated on the respiratory, food or phonatory difficulties reported after surgery as well as on the result of early postoperative nasofibroscopy.

arm_group.arm_group_label: No laryngeal mobility disorder post cardiac surgery
arm_group.description: No Follow up, no questionnaires and no nasofibroscopic control.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Laryngeal mobility disorder post cardiac surgery
arm_group.description: During a follow-up consultation, questionnaires will be offered to assess the child's quality of life.

intervention.description: To explore the quality of life, two questionnaires will be submitted to the parents and the child. The first one is the pediatric version of the VHI (Voice Handicap Index), which explore, using 23 items, the functional, physical and emotional aspects of the dysphonia. The second one is the PEDI-EAT-10 (Pediatric Voice Handicap Index - Eating Assessment Tool), which explore, through 10 items (ranging from 0 to 4), the risk of aspiration and assess the impact of possible dysphagia on quality of life.
intervention.arm_group_label: Laryngeal mobility disorder post cardiac surgery

study_pop.textblock: Children between 5 and 10 years old, having undergone a nasofibroscopy following cardiac surgery performed before their first year of life (between 01/01/2010 and 12/31/2015).

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- No opposition from children and parents
- Patient or parents able to understand the ins and outs of the study
Exclusion Criteria:
- None
